description: From Middle English ax, axe, ex, from Old English æx, from Proto-West Germanic *akusi, from Proto-Germanic *akwisī, probably from a Proto-Indo-European *h₂egʷsih₂ (“axe”), from *h₂eḱ- (“sharp, pointed”). Compare German Axt, Dutch aks, Danish økse, Icelandic öxi, and also Latin ascia.

entries.meaning: A tool for felling trees or chopping wood etc. consisting of a heavy  head flattened to a blade on one side, and a  handle attached to it.
An ancient weapon consisting of a  head that has one or two blades and a long handle.

examples: Synonyms: chop, pink slip, sack, boot
His girlfriend/boss/schoolmaster gave him the axe.

entries.meaning: (slang, music) A gigging musician's particular instrument, especially a guitar in rock music or a saxophone in jazz.
(finance) A position, interest, or reason in buying and selling stock, often with ulterior motives.
examples: A financial dealer has an axe in a stock that his buyers don't know about, giving him an advantage in making the most profit.

verbs.description: axe (third-person singular simple present axes, present participle axing, simple past and past participle axed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To fell or chop with an axe.
(transitive, figurative) To lay off, terminate or drastically reduce, especially in a rough or ruthless manner; to cancel.
examples: Synonyms: downsize, fire, lay off; see also Thesaurus:lay off
The government announced its plans to axe public spending.
The broadcaster axed the series because far fewer people than expected watched it.
He got axed in the last round of firings.

verbs.description: axe (third-person singular simple present axes, present participle axing, simple past and past participle axed)

description: Old English axian (“ask”); see ax for more.

verbs.description: axe (third-person singular simple present axes, present participle axing, simple past and past participle axed)

entries.meaning: (now obsolete outside dialects, especially African-American Vernacular) Alternative form of ask
